body.p: This section explains how to work with patches in .

section.title: What is a Patch
section.p: Suppose you are working with a set of XML files that you want to tag the project and distribute releases to other team members. While working on the project and correcting problems, you may need to distribute the corrections to other team members. In this case, you can distribute a patch (a collection of differences) that would correct the problems when applied over the last distribution. By default, the generates patches in the Unified Diff format, but it can also use the Git format.
Creating a patch in implies the access to either two revisions of a versioned item, or two different versioned items from the repository:

ul.li: Two revisions of a version item - the item can be local or remote and you can select two versions of it. This also applies when you need to generate a patch that only contains the changes in the working copy that were not yet committed.
Two different versioned items from the repository - the items are remote and you need to specify a revision for both.

section.note: The resulting patch file may contain content that was written using a mix of encodings, based upon the encodings of the files that were compared. If you open the generated patch file in a text editor, it may result in unrecognizable content.
